column4: body
Uncover what truly matters to the guest (needs + motivations) while building trust through clarity, empathy, and a consistent, guest-first process.
By the end of this module, the team can run a structured needs conversation that feels natural, earns permission, and produces a clear ‘Needs Map’ for vehicle selection.
column5: Needs Map|Permission-based questions|Summarize + confirm|Smooth transition to selection

column4: A guided conversation that helps guests feel understood and respected—so we can recommend the right solution without pressure.
Guests don’t resist questions—they resist feeling ‘worked.’ Trust is built when questions have a clear purpose and lead to helpful next steps.
Your job is to understand before you recommend. We earn the right to present options by listening deeply and confirming we ‘got it.’
column6: Seek first to understand, then to be understood.

column4: Curiosity keeps the guest relaxed. Control makes the guest defensive. Lead with calm questions, not commands.
Permission-based questions reduce resistance and increase cooperation.
column5: Is it okay if…|Do you mind if…|Can I ask…

column4: Explain WHY you’re asking. Guests trust questions that help them, not questions that help us close.
Great discovery reduces uncertainty. When guests feel understood, they become more open, honest, and decisive.
Too many options create stress. Clear needs reduce choice overload and speed up decisions.
Guests fear making a wrong choice more than they desire a ‘good deal.’ Discovery lowers regret risk.
Trust grows when we listen, reflect, and keep promises (even small ones).
People cooperate when they feel choice and autonomy. Discovery should feel like collaboration, not interrogation.
A consistent process feels safer than a random experience. Guests relax when the path is clear.
These behaviors make discovery feel helpful, professional, and calm.
Before questions, explain what happens next in one minute so the guest knows the ‘why.’
column5: What we’ll do|How long|What you’ll get

column4: Begin with open questions, then narrow into must-haves and constraints.
For every recommendation or feature, ask 3 questions first.
Avoid leading questions that push a model or outcome.
Summarize what you heard, then ask the guest to confirm or correct it.
Help guests rank what matters most before showing vehicles.
Respectfully clarify who is involved in the decision and what they care about.
column5: Who else?|What matters to them?|Next step

column4: Ask about timing in a non-pushy way. Align the plan to their timeframe.
Understand current vehicle satisfaction and pain points before recommending changes.
Write notes in a way that feels collaborative, not like you’re building leverage.
column8: “I’m taking notes so I don’t miss anything.”

column4: The Needs Map is the output of discovery: what they do, what they need, what they feel, and what matters most.
Cover these in order: lifestyle/usage, passengers/cargo, must-haves, comfort/tech, budget approach, timeline, trade, decision-makers.
column8: Use as a checklist in your app.

column4: Ask one question that reveals the ‘why’ behind the purchase—this is where trust deepens.
Clarify constraints without making it about money pressure.
Use these scripts as patterns—adapt tone, keep structure.
Bridge from greeting into discovery with permission and purpose.
Welcome in—so I can be helpful and not waste your time, is it okay if I ask a few quick questions about what you’re looking for?
Set expectations and reduce anxiety.
Perfect. Here’s what we’ll do: I’ll ask a few questions, we’ll narrow it to 2–3 best-fit options, then you can decide what you want to see first. Sound good?
Begin broad and guest-centered.
What brought you in today—and what would make this a great outcome for you?
Make the vehicle about their real life.
Walk me through a normal week—commute, family, trips, weather—how will this vehicle actually be used?
Turn preferences into priorities.
If we had to narrow it down, what are your top three must-haves—and what’s nice but not required?
Use gentle options and give them control.
No worries—some people like to think it through. Would you rather start with size (SUV vs sedan) or with your top priority (payment comfort vs features)?
Lead with transparency and autonomy.
Totally fair—shopping can feel stressful. My goal is to make this simple. You stay in control; I’ll just guide the process and you tell me what fits.
Acknowledge, give clarity, then add context by needs.
Absolutely—price matters. We keep it simple with one clear price so there’s no back-and-forth. Before I point you to the best option, what matters most in the vehicle?
column8: Aligns with one-price without getting defensive.

column4: Stay respectful and plan next step.
That makes sense. When you think about the other person involved, what do you think matters most to them—so we can make sure we don’t miss it?
Keep it simple and value-focused.
What are you driving now—and what do you love about it? What do you wish was better?
These kill trust fast—coach them out early.
Rapid-fire questions with no purpose explanation feels like a trap.
Talking features before needs feels salesy and random.
column5: Ask first|Tie features to needs|2–3 options

column4: Jumping to payment before value increases resistance.
Trust dies when we promise and don’t deliver.
Practice discovery that feels natural: tone, pacing, permission, and summarizing.
column6: If you listen, people will tell you exactly what they need.

column4: Run 5-minute reps and score them using the coaching cues.
Score: agenda set, # of open questions, permission language, summary accuracy, must-have ranking, next-step clarity.
Turn discovery into a repeatable habit by reflecting on real guest conversations.
Did my questions feel helpful to the guest—or helpful to me? What proof do I have?
Write a Needs Map for your last 3 guests and circle the top 3 must-haves you confirmed out loud.
List one trust behavior you did well and one you’ll improve next shift.
We coach behaviors we can see and measure.
Every guest has a documented Needs Map before vehicle selection (notes in CRM or worksheet).
Guest can repeat their top 3 must-haves and agrees with your summary before you present options.
Present only 2–3 best-fit options based on confirmed priorities.
